docs.snippet: Dear readers, what questions can the Carpetbagger answer for you about the Oscar season?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Borrowing on our grand tradition of gambits when we run out of things to write about, the Bagger would now like to go the crowd-sourcing route. What would you, dear readers, like to know about? One commenter has written asking for an interview with an Oscar-nominated costume designer; we're working on it! What else do you have lingering questions about (that our film critic colleagues A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, can't answer)? As we wrote last year (look, we're too drained to even produce new copy!), the Bagger is open to any and all reasonable queries and will gladly use the power of having The New York Times as a last name to get your questions answered. Leave them in the comments below or e-mail us at carpetbagger@nytimes.com.
docs.abstract: Dear readers, what questions can the Carpetbagger answer for you about the Oscar season?

docs.snippet: Another day of runway looks, another Scorecard at your service....
docs.lead_paragraph: On the penultimate day of New York fashion week, America's stealth luxury master Michael Kors was in a reflective mood as he rang in the big 3-0, and other designers too took the opportunity to brush up on their fashion history. Oscar de la Renta looked back to his own '60s archives for a glamorous collection for Park Avenue princesses that was OTT, even by ODLR standards. Meanwhile, Scorecard knows critics felt the Proenza Schouler mavericks showed true grit with their pixelated Navajo prints. That's how the West Village was won.
docs.abstract: Another day of runway looks, another Scorecard at your service.

docs.snippet: The photographer Danielle Levitt discusses her new show, "Pride of Lowell," at Los Angeles's Known Gallery....
docs.lead_paragraph: The photographer Danielle Levitt has an eye for disaffected youth. Her 2008 monograph "We Are Experienced" compiled more than 100 portraits of American teenagers taken over several years as Levitt hopscotched across the country shooting features and fashion editorials for Interview, Arena Homme Plus and The New York Times Magazine, among many others. Levitt began her career shooting a street style column for The Wall Street Journal, a natural window onto the downtown scene, and her work has evolved to include "werewolves" in Texas for Dazed & Confused and sissy bouncers for Arena Homme Plus. This fall, she was sent to Lowell, Mass., to shoot Mickey Ward and Dicky Eklund, the real-life characters behind David O. Russell's Oscar-nominated film "The Fighter"; the magazine assignment turned into a new series of portraits and a collection of short films. "Pride of Lowell," curated by Naheed Simjee, will opened on Wednesday at Los Angeles's Known Gallery. T caught up with Levitt via e-mail to talk about the show.
docs.abstract: The photographer Danielle Levitt discusses her new show, "Pride of Lowell," at Los Angeles's Known Gallery.

headline.main: Fight Club | Danielle Levitt's 'Pride of Lowell'

docs.snippet: Movie buffs eager to get up close to some Oscar glamour have several options across the country....
docs.lead_paragraph: Movie buffs eager to get up close to some Oscar glamour have a few options across the country. In New York, head to Grand Central for the Academy's annual "Meet the Oscars" exhibit, in which you can put your grubby paws all over the naked little guy, for a few seconds at least. In Times Square, you can get yourself photographed with a virtual Oscar, and experience a few seconds of red carpet fame. But for the real deal experience we recommend getting a bunch of your photoblogger friends together and having them shout and point at you as you stand in front of a cardboard backdrop. Then stop to chat awkwardly with Ryan Seacrest, or maybe the Naked Cowboy.
docs.abstract: Movie buffs eager to get up close to some Oscar glamour have several options across the country.

headline.main: Meet the Oscars, at Grand Central
